Award.AwardTitle: SNM: Scaling Directed Self-Assembly of Block Copolymers for Sub 10 nm Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding to address fundamental and technological issues essential for the widespread implementation of directed self-assembly (DSA) in nanomanufacturing of device structures. Specifically, block copolymers, that self-assemble to form densely packed features with highly uniform dimensions and shapes in ordered arrays, will be directed to assemble on chemical pre-patterns defined using traditional lithographic processes, such as 193 nm immersion or electron beam lithography. Hence, the 20 to 40 nm resolution of traditional lithography will be reduced down to the 5 to 10 nm range by DSA. The principal activities of the proposed work include fabrication of ultrathin and high resolution chemically nanopatterned substrates to enable DSA at 10 nm feature size and below; development of strategies to deposit surface layers on top of self-assembling block copolymer films as a means to enable high-resolution assemblies; and all vapor-phase synthesis, deposition, and directed self-assembly of block copolymers. Novel and scalable processes for chemical vapor deposition of polymeric nanocoatings are a key to all activities, and the proposed effort represents a truly concerted computational and experimental approach, with design of materials and processes enabled by predictive molecular simulations.

This research, which aims to establish a proven pathway to realize sub 10 nm resolution, and provide scaling down to 5 nm, has the potential to revolutionize nanolithography and nanomanufacturing. For the semiconductor industry, DSA may allow the manufacture of future generations of faster computer chips following Moore?s law without having to invest billions of dollars in new fabrication facilities (i.e. based on extreme ultra violet lithography) that may or may not be able to meet the required resolutions. For hard drives, block copolymer lithography is the only known technology that is feasible to fabricate nanoimprint masters to manufacture bit patterned media at the required storage densities (at least greater than 2 Terabit/inch2). The research will also substantially advance the state-of-the-art in vapor-phase deposition of polymers with controlled compositions and molecular architectures, and that of predictive and quantitative models for the thermodynamics and dynamics of polymer films.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A key concept articulated by the NSF Scalable Nanomanufacturing Program (SNM) is that although many nanofabrication techniques have demonstrated the ability to fabricate small quantities of nanomaterials and nanostructures for characterization and evaluation purposes, tremendous challenges remain to overcome the key scientific and engineering barriers that prevent their integration into nanodevices and nanosystems at an industrially relevant scale. These stated objectives of the SNM program served as a catalyst to:  1) form an interdisciplinary team consisting of the following lead investigators and skill sets: Juan de Pablo (University of Chicago) - molecular simulation and theory, Karen Gleason (MIT) - initiated chemical vapor deposition of polymers (iCVD),  and Paul Nealey (University of Chicago) - directed self-assembly (DSA), and 2) establish critical links to imec, an industrial-scale research and development facility in Belgium that is focused on semiconductor manufacturing, including the possibility for students working on the project to perform internships. The research was aimed at impactful extensions of DSA technology at the level of basic science and proof-of-principle demonstrations, and the connection with imec provided direct pathways to realistic analysis of the technology for industrial implementation. This team would not have formed without the SNM program. Additionally, the proposed research may not have been funded without the specific, clear objectives of the SNM program to include often neglected but impactful components of research related to the industrially relevant scale.

Here are just four telling and interrelated highlights of the research that we accomplished in the context of the SNM program: 1) extended iCVD as a means to deposit conformal, nanometer thin polymers layers with controlled surface and interfacial properties on substrates and on the surfaces of block copolymer films (Basic Science); 2) demonstrated that such iCVD films could be used as generalizable topcoats for the DSA of high resolution block copolymers, without the need for removal prior to pattern transfer (Basic Science / Proof-of-Principle), or could be used in situ for cut-mask strategies; 3)  used iCVD directly on wafers fabricated at imec to control polymer wetting properties for the DSA hole shrink processes (Development); and 4) delineated and optimized the allowable properties of chemically patterned templates consisting of mats and brushes for DSA using industrially relevant materials and tools at imec (Development).

This funding led to 28 publications, including 19 journal articles, 7 conference papers, and 2 book chapters. The research outcomes were presented to the scientific and industrial community at 15 conference presentations and 42 invited talks and were well received. Our SNM project led to collaborations with national labs (National Institute of Standards and Technology and Argonne National Lab) as well as with industry (CEA Leti, imec, Intel, and Seagate). Five graduate students spent a year and a half each interning at imec, one graduate student interned at NASA, and one postdoc interned at Seagate. In total, five post-docs, ten graduate students, and one undergraduate student benefitted from the training they received while working on the program. Many of them have found jobs in the semiconductor industry where they will continue the transfer of advance patterning knowledge to high volume manufacturing.


Last Modified: 03/06/2019
Modified by: Paul F Nealey

This team would not have formed without the SNM program. Additionally, the proposed research may not have been funded without the specific, clear objectives of the SNM program to include often neglected but impactful components of research related to the industrially relevant scale. Here are just four telling and interrelated highlights of the research that we accomplished in the context of the SNM program: 1) extended iCVD as a means to deposit conformal, nanometer thin polymers layers with controlled surface and interfacial properties on substrates and on the surfaces of block copolymer films (Basic Science); 2) demonstrated that such iCVD films could be used as generalizable topcoats for the DSA of high resolution block copolymers, without the need for removal prior to pattern transfer (Basic Science / Proof-of-Principle), or could be used in situ for cut-mask strategies; 3) used iCVD directly on wafers fabricated at imec to control polymer wetting properties for the DSA hole shrink processes (Development); and 4) delineated and optimized the allowable properties of chemically patterned templates consisting of mats and brushes for DSA using industrially relevant materials and tools at imec (Development). This funding led to 28 publications, including 19 journal articles, 7 conference papers, and 2 book chapters. The research outcomes were presented to the scientific and industrial community at 15 conference presentations and 42 invited talks and were well received. Our SNM project led to collaborations with national labs (National Institute of Standards and Technology and Argonne National Lab) as well as with industry (CEA Leti, imec, Intel, and Seagate). Five graduate students spent a year and a half each interning at imec, one graduate student interned at NASA, and one postdoc interned at Seagate. In total, five post-docs, ten graduate students, and one undergraduate student benefitted from the training they received while working on the program. Many of them have found jobs in the semiconductor industry where they will continue the transfer of advance patterning knowledge to high volume manufacturing.
